comparative advantage trade is when a country specializes in producing one good and then buys from other countries for the other goods it produces.

factor cost is the price of a factor of production.

foreign market is the market that has a different price for a good than the country that produces the good.

comparative advantage trade is when a country specializes in producing one good and then buys from other countries for the other goods it produces. Trade balance is a difference between the imports and exports of a country.

factor pricing refers to the price of a factor of production.

How does TASCA work?

TASCA is a protein that binds to a specific DNA sequence in the genome to activate the CRISPR/Cas9 system. The CRISPR/Cas9 system is a molecular tool used in genome engineering that can be programmed to bind to a specific DNA sequence and cleave it. user_prompt: What do you get by substituting the oxygen in the isocyanate group with a sulfur?
assistant_prompt:
.

The answer is a diphenylmethane diisocyanate.

The compound is so strong it can be used in place of the methylene diphenyl di isocyanate (MDI) that's otherwise used to make polyurethanes.

"The advantage of this reaction is that it gives you a very tough polyurethane, which is a very useful polymer," said Toshio Kurita, a chemist at Nihon University in Japan.

The reaction is likely to be used commercially in the near future, Kurita said.

The discovery was reported online in the current issue of the Journal of Organic Chemistry.

(Editor's note: Paul Laudon is a science writer based in New York. His work has appeared in The Washington Post, The New York Times, and The Los Angeles Times, among other publications.)

Copyright 2014 NPR. To see more, visit http://www.npr.org/.

Transcript

ROBERT SIEGEL, HOST:

The chemical industry is in the midst of a revolution. The key to this revolution is a chemical reaction. It's the chance to use a powerful chemical, a molecule containing sulfur, instead of one containing oxygen.

NPR science correspondent Paul Laudon has been reporting on this chemical reaction, and we're going to hear about it in a minute. But first, we wanted to learn more about the reaction itself. So I called Toshio Kurita, a chemist at Nihon University in Japan.

TOSHIO KURITA: The reaction is very easy to do.

SIEGEL: What do you do?

KURITA: You take a compound containing two primary amines, and you add hydrogen cyanide.

SIEGEL: Hydrogen cyanide?

KURITA: Hydrogen cyanide is a very strong base.

SIEGEL: You're talking about potassium cyanide?

KURITA: We used potassium cyanide. It gives you a very tough polyurethane, which is a very useful polymer.

SIEGEL: So you have a two-step process. First, you make the compound containing the two primary amines. Then you use a strong acid to remove the hydrogen cyanide.

KURITA: Yes.

SIEGEL: So tell me - tell me what has happened to the hydrogen cyanide

Dairy-free: almond milk

I’ve found that almond milk can be used as a dairy-free alternative in a number of recipes. You can make it with water or use the recipe below.

1 cup almonds

1/2 cup water

1/4 cup coconut sugar

1/4 cup sunflower seeds

1 tbsp almond butter

1 tsp vanilla extract

Soak the almonds in the water overnight, or for at least 6 hours, or for about 8 hours if you can.

Drain the almonds and grind them in a blender or food processor until they’re very finely ground. Add the sugar, seeds, and almond butter and blend to make a thick paste.

Transfer the paste to a bowl and mix in the vanilla.

ear (Hobo) is a series of books written by Gertrude Chandler Warner and published by Twayne, a division of Macmillan Publishing Company, for children. The series was originally published from 1940 to 1953; Warner re-published the first three titles in the series in 1996. The publisher is now Macmillan Children's Publishing Group.

The first book in the series was published in 1940, and the series was aimed at children between the ages of eight and twelve.  Later titles were aimed at children aged six and up, and the series aimed to teach children how to count, read, write, and spell.

Early series
Gertrude Chandler Warner wrote the series under the pseudonym "Hobo", and also wrote under the pseudonym "Hobo" the previously uncollected stories "Buster's Spree" and "Buster's New York".

Warner also wrote under the pseudonym "Hobo" the novels Ginger Pye and The Secret of the Old Clock and the booklet for the series The Story of the Wizard of Oz, published in 1939.

List of series

Series 1
 Title: The Little House
 Inspired by the life of the author's mother, Gertrude Chandler Warner, the novel covers the entire series with the early years of the author's life. The protagonist, Marion, is a tomboy in the series, and her mother is the only person to ever call her "Marion" instead of "Mary." This book was the first in the series.
 Publisher: Twayne Publishers
 Year Published: 1940

Series 2
 Title: A Little House in the Woods

 Year Published: 1941

Series 3

Water hammer can cause pipes to burst. If the pressure in your water supply pipe is too high, the water supply pipe can burst.

user_prompt: What is DevSecOps?
assistant_prompt:
.in/devsecops

DevSecOps is a new, more integrated approach to security that brings together security teams and software developers to help maintain the security of the software before it is released to production.

How does DevSecOps work?

In DevSecOps, the security team and the software development team work together to ensure that the software is secure before it is released to production.

This is done by practicing Continuous Integration, Continuous Deployment, Continuous Testing, and Continuous Monitoring.

Continuous Integration means that both teams practice Continuous Integration, which means that the code is checked in to version control very frequently. This speeds up the process of producing quality software by preventing regressions and detecting bugs faster.

Continuous Deployment means that both teams practice Continuous Deployment, which means that the code is almost continuously deployed to production. This ensures that the software is secure as soon as it is released, and makes it easier to rollback changes if they are found to be insecure.

Continuous Testing means that both teams practice Continuous Testing, which means that the software is constantly tested for security and quality. This makes it possible to detect and fix bugs faster, and ensures that the software is secure when it is released to production.

Continuous Monitoring means that both teams practice Continuous Monitoring, which means that the software is constantly monitored for security vulnerabilities. This makes it possible to quickly fix security vulnerabilities before they can cause problems.

The DevSecOps approach is based on the YAGNI principle, which means "you aren't going to need it".

This means that security flaws that are found in the software are fixed before they become serious security problems. This reduces the time and effort that is needed to create secure software.

How is DevSecOps different from Continuous Integration, Continuous Deployment, Continuous Testing, and Continuous Monitoring?

Continuous Integration, Continuous Deployment, Continuous Testing, and Continuous Monitoring are all different types of Continuous Integration, and all these methods are used together to ensure that the software is secure before it is released to production.

However, these methods are not the same.

For example, Continuous Integration is a continuous integration method, which means that it is a method that is practiced by both the software development and the security teams.

However, Continuous Deployment is a continuous deployment method, which means that it is a method that is practiced by only the software development team.

DevSecOps is a more integrated approach

select u.userid, u.nick from users u join nicknames n on n.userid = u.userid

The present invention relates to a method of manufacturing a semiconductor device, and more particularly to a semiconductor device manufacturing method, that can prevent an oxide film from being peeled off from a side wall of a trench.
As the semiconductor industry has developed in recent years, the size of a transistor has been continuously reduced. As the size of a transistor is reduced, the width of a channel region is also reduced. As the width of a channel region is reduced, a short channel effect is generated. The short channel effect causes problems such as drain induced barrier lowering (DIBL), hot carrier effect, and the like.
To solve these problems, a salicide (self-aligned silicide) process has been proposed. The salicide process reduces the width of a channel region and thereby suppresses the short channel effect.
The salicide process is a process in which, when a gate electrode and a source/drain region are formed, a metal is deposited on a substrate including the gate electrode and the source/drain region by using a salicide process.
The salicide process forms a metal silicide layer having a low resistivity on a surface of a semiconductor substrate, and thereby limits the resistance of the source/drain region and the gate electrode.
FIGS. 1A through 1E are cross-sectional views illustrating a method of manufacturing a semiconductor device according to a conventional art.
Referring to FIG. 1A, a semiconductor substrate 1 on which a device isolation region 2 is formed is provided. A field oxide film (not shown) is formed on the semiconductor substrate 1 by using a conventional photolithographic process.
Referring to FIG. 1B, a thin insulating layer 3, which is made of silicon oxide (SiO2), is formed on the semiconductor substrate

in the atmosphere ?

A turbulent air flow can be defined as having a significant variation of speed of flow across its surface. So, the flow is not constant through out its surface.

For example: If a liquid is flowing on a plane surface, the flow will be in the middle of the plane and will be constant through out it.

If the same liquid is flowing on an inclined plane surface, the flow will be as shown in the figure. As the flow is taking place on the inclined plane surface, the flow will be in the middle of the plane and will be changing continuously from the left to right and from the right to left. This is the reason for the turbulence.

Now, if the liquid is flowing on a cylinder surface, as the liquid is flowing on the cylinder surface, the flow will be in the middle of the cylinder. But as the cylinder increases in length, the flow will be constant through out the cylinder. This is the reason for the laminar flow.

So, turbulent flow is the flow when the flow is not constant through out its surface.

This is a nice example of how to use the handy self.method() function. See the previous tutorial.

It can also be used outside of class.

>>> def dostuff():
... ... print 'hello'
... ...
>>> d = dostuff
>>> d.method()
hello
>>>

Another method of the class is the __getattr__ function.

def __getattr__(self, name):
return getattr(self, name)

You can use this to access the attribute in a "special" way.

>>> class A(object):
... ... def __init__(self):
... ... self.aString = "test"
... ...
... ... def __getattr__(self, name):
... ... print name
... ... return getattr(self, name)
... ...
... ...
>>> d = A()
>>> d.aString
test
>>> d.aString.method()
Traceback (most recent call last):
File "<stdin>", line 1, in <module>
AttributeError: 'A' object has no attribute 'aString'
>>>

An important tool is the getattr function.

>>> getattr(d, 'aString')
test
>>>

The self.method function can be used inside the getattr function:

>>> getattr(d, 'aString')
test
>>>

You can also get the attributes of a class, like this:

>>> d.class.attribute
test
>>>

But when you want to get the attribute of a method, you need to give the name of the method.

>>> d.class.method.attribute
test
>>>

If you want to get the attribute of a function, you must give the name of the function.

>>> d.class.method.function.attribute
test
